ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Sooo much. I learned how to write concisely. I also learned alot of sociological concepts that I have started to notice in the real world aswell.
Provides a good introduction of criminological theories

I learned how to apply criminological theories to real-world cases, rather than just learning them and moving on. I also gained insight in viewing different theories not as separate entities, but as separate layers, each built upon the previous, in the grand scheme of criminology. While different theories may be contradicting others, all are necessary to building a solid foundation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This has nothing to do with Mattias, but I think the Yale Course Search description of the class was a bit inaccurate. This is not really a criminology class in the way that people unfamiliar with sociology would think. You dont really learn about killers from a psychological standpoint. I realized this during add drop but decided to keep the course because it showed that I had alot to learn about sociology, and I am glad that I did!! I think this is the perfect intro course if you are deciding you want to be a SOCY major, or if ur interested in criminology.

strength - material and flow of the course was pretty straight forward and interesting, with a fairly manageable workload and organized classes

weakness - was already a fairly small seminar, and felt that the additional discussion section was not the most necessary
strengths- professor is really helpful and understanding

A big strength of the course was how the midterm and final papers were structured. Rather than regurgitating definitions of theories, we were asked to apply real-life criminal cases to the theories we learned. For the final paper, we applied the theories to an article about the prison system. These assessments solidified my understanding of the concepts and I finished both papers feeling more knowledgable of the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 100% Mattias is an amazing professor and he makes class very fun and personal. I wish I could take another one of his classes, genuinely the best prof I had this semester.
i would recommend the class for the most part, if students are interested in criminology, as the content of the course is relatively interesting and the workload is pretty manageable.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It's very applicable to our current society and has made me think about our legal system as well as how we treat those who commit crimes. It's a very interesting and relevant course that everyone should take.
Only if strongly interested in crime.
